issues.description: The problem statement specifies acceptSupplyDelivery with four parameters (supplier name, ingredient name, price, quantity): acceptSupplyDelivery(String, String, int, int). The solution implementation defines acceptSupplyDelivery with only three parameters (ingredient name, price, quantity): acceptSupplyDelivery(String, int, int). This is a method-parameter mismatch that could confuse students about the required signature and lead to inconsistencies with tests or graders that expect the signature described in the problem.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the method signatures consistent. Either update the solution to accept the supplier parameter (e.g., public static void acceptSupplyDelivery(String supplierName, String ingredientName, int price, int quantity)) and ignore or store the supplier name, or change the problem statement/UML to require only three parameters (ingredient name, price, quantity). Preferably, modify the solution to match the problem statement (add the supplier String parameter) to avoid changing the specification students read.

issues.description: The problem statement (UML and textual spec) defines acceptSupplyDelivery with four parameters (supplier name, ingredient name, price, quantity) -> acceptSupplyDelivery(String, String, int, int). The solution's SealSaloon implements acceptSupplyDelivery as acceptSupplyDelivery(String name, int price, int quantity) — i.e., it omits the supplier-name parameter and collapses the expected two-String parameters into one. This creates a clear mismatch between the requirement and the provided implementation: students reading the problem will expect a method that accepts a supplier identifier and an ingredient identifier, but the solution (and therefore the target implementation) uses a different signature and parameter naming, causing confusion about which conceptual entities must be provided and in what order.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the method signatures consistent. Either (A) update the solution (and any template) to implement the four-parameter signature required by the problem: public static void acceptSupplyDelivery(String supplierName, String ingredientName, int price, int quantity) — using supplierName as an (optional) metadata argument and ingredientName when updating stock; or (B) if supplier information is intentionally irrelevant, update the problem statement and UML to specify the three-parameter signature currently used (ingredientName, price, quantity). Recommended: prefer (A) to match the problem UML and avoid student confusion.
